description.en: The course begins by looking at the main patterns of political transformation in the region in the late 1980s - early 1990s, during and immediately after the collapse of the Soviet Union. In the second part, the typology of the evolution of political regimes in the following decades is introduced, and their current state is discussed. In doing that, the course relies upon the literature on democratization, as well as on the more recent works on the varieties of authoritarianism. The third part of the course consists of country cases that illustrate typical post-Soviet political trajectories and outcomes, ranging between oligarchical pluralism and authoritarian dictatorships. Topics considered for each country vary depending on the their relative importance for the specific case, but in most cases, the list includes constitution and the form of government, relations between the branches of power, political parties and interest groups, corruption, the state of fundamental rights and freedoms. Critical engagement with the concept of transition is a key element of all course sessions.
description.et: Kõigepealt vaadeldakse poliitilise siirde mustreid endise Nõukogude Liidu alal asuvates riikides 1980ndate lõpus ja 90ndate alguses. Seejärel käsitletakse järgmiste kümnendite poliitiliste režiimide arengu tüpoloogiat ja tänast olukorda. Kursuse kolmas osa keskendub konkreetsete juhtumite uurimisele, mis on headeks näideteks tüüpilistest N. Liidu järgsetest poliitilistest arengutest ja tulemustest.

objectives.en: The course presents a comparative overview of political systems in the post-Soviet space, focusing on the critical re-assessment of the transition paradigm. It introduces a typology of regimes and discusses the main factors behind the diverging trajectories of political transformations.
objectives.et: Kursus annab võrdleva ülevaate endise Nõukogude Liidu alal asuvate riikide poliitilistest süteemidest, keskendudes siirdeparadigma kriitilisele ümberhindamisele. Kursus tutvustab režiimide tüpoloogiat ja arutleb poliitiliste arengute lahknevate trajektooride põhjuste üle.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon the completion of the course, the students will be able to:
1) understand the typology of political regimes in the post-Soviet space and the general trends in their evolution;
learning_outcomes.et: 1) saab aru endise Nõukogude Liidu alal asuvate riikide poliitiliste režiimide tüpoloogiast ning nende arengu üldistest trendidest;

learning_outcomes.en: 2) become aware of the main theoretical approaches to the political developments in the post-Soviet space, including literature on democratisation and varieties of authoritarianism;
learning_outcomes.et: 2) teab peamisi teoreetilisi lähtepunkte endise Nõukogude Liidu alal asuvate riikide poliitilise arengu mõistmiseks, k.a demokratiseerumise ja autoritaarsete režiimide alast kirjandust;

learning_outcomes.en: 3) critically re-evaluate the transition paradigm as the mainstream approach instrumental in shaping political practices;
learning_outcomes.et: 3) oskab kriitiliselt hinnata siirdeparadigmat kui poliitiliste praktikate kujundamise põhilist lähenemist;

learning_outcomes.en: 4) become aware of the most important literature and sources on post-Soviet politics and be able to independently obtain information on the current developments in the region;
learning_outcomes.et: 4) teab kõige olulisemaid allikaid postsotsialistliku poliitika kohta ning oskab iseseisvalt leida informatsiooni praeguste arengute kohta regioonis;

learning_outcomes.en: 5) formulate an informed opinion about current political developments in the post-Soviet space.
learning_outcomes.et: 5) oskab forumleerida ja kaitsta oma seisukohti tänapäevaste poliitiliste arengute kohta antud regioonis.

independent_work.et: Most classes will include a combination of an introductory lecture and a seminar based on the readings. The students are expected to attend all classes, do compulsory readings before each class, and actively take part in seminar discussions. Failure to do so will result in a reduction of the attendance and participation score.

description.et: COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS: In this small group exercise students will need to compare two post-Soviet countries along the lines discussed in the classes: mechanisms of diffusion, the role of external actors, the functioning of governments and non-governmental / civil society actors (including the church when appropriate) and the media. This assignment includes both in-class presentation and submission of research note

ONLINE COLLOQUIUM. This is a series of online fora for extended discussions of issues touched upon in the classes and in the reading materials. Each month we'll address a particular topic / question / political controversy related to transformation of political institutions and practices in post-Soviet countries.Students are expected to participate in each of the four forums with their statements, remarks and questions, based on the content of the lectures and on home reading texts. The minimal number of entries for each forum is two, but only those of them will count that address substantial and meaningful aspects of the discussed topic, engage with the extant literature and contribute to the debate with new arguments.
A (45-50 points): contributions to all three colloquiums are highly substantive and meaningful both in form and in content; they triggered further debate and provoked multiple questions, remarks and comments from other participants
B (35-45 points): solid and empirically relevant opinions supported by references to facts and literature; more descriptive than analytical
C (25-35 points): submissions are pertinent to the topic, yet more monological than engaging with group mates' inputs; more asking questions rather than giving answers
D (15-25 points): submissions are informative, yet non-systemic, repetitive and largely detached from the overall debate, with minimal cross-references to other participants
E (10-15 points): contributions to the debate are short and mostly rhetorical, with no substantial contribution to the discussion and only little communication with other participants
F (less than 10 points) - failed

grade_preconditions.et: In order to be graded, the students must attend at least two thirds of all classes, complete all compulsory readings, and fulfill two assignments.

grade_evaluation.et:
Final grade for the course will be based on the following criteria:
Participation in online colloquium - 50 %
Comparative analysis (group work) -  25 %
Individual research note - 25 %

debt_elimination.et: By individual agreement with the instructor.

description.et:
Introduction to the course. 
Focal points: "political systems" and "the post-Soviet space"
Historical legacies of independence (1918-2018): debates in Baltic states, countries of Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus

The Soviet collapse and the emergence of post-Soviet statehood
The post-Soviet / post-socialist nation state and its pitfalls

The post-Soviet governance: experiences and trajectories of transition, transformation, diffusion, policy transfer practices and spill-over effects
Liberal democracies and illiberal non-democracies

Domestic and external factors shaping post-Soviet regimes-in-the-making. 
The concept of regime change.
"Color revolutions" and "Russian spring"
Case study: Maidan and anti-Maidan

Post-Soviet ethnopolitics and its repercussions.
Internal conflicts and challenges of separatism / secession / irredentism

Cultural legacies and dimensions of political transitions
Religion as a political institution: post-Soviet controversies
Right-wing nationalism: parties and groups (cases: Ukraine and Georgia)
Civil societies, NGOs and public policy institutions in post-Soviet countries
Sub-national authorities in post-Soviet countries (Russia, Ukraine, Georgia, Moldova)
Final discussion: summing up, lessons drawing and conclusion

audience.et: Course is open for all interested
